Directions

In this Demonstration, the pressure on a fluid is measured using a piezometer, a U-tube manometer and an inclined-tube manometer. Use the buttons to select the type of manometer and the manometer fluid (water, oil or mercury). You can change the fluid pressure and the angle of the inclined manometer with the sliders. On the inclined manometer, lengths may not appear exactly to-scale.

Details

A piezometer consists of a vertical tube open to atmospheric pressure at one end. A force balance determines the height of the fluid:

$$ \mathrm{[1]} \; \; P_{o} = P_{a} + \gamma_{o} h $$

where \( P_{o} \) is the hydrostatic pressure, \( P_{a} \) is atmospheric pressure, \( \gamma_{o} \) is specific weight of the fluid, and \( h \) the height of fluid in the piezometer. Specific weight is defined:

$$ \mathrm{[2]} \; \; \gamma_{o} = \rho_{o} g $$

where \( \rho_{o} \) is density of the fluid and \( g \) is the gravitational constant, 9.81 m/s2.

In a U-tube manometer, there are two components: the fluid being measured and the manometer fluid, which is typically a dense, non-volatile liquid such as mercury. An advantage of the U-tube manometer is that the fluid being measured can be a gas or liquid, whereas the piezometer can only measure liquid pressure. For a U-tube manometer, a force balance is used to calculate pressure:

$$ \mathrm{[3]} \; \; P_{o} + \gamma_{o} h = P_{a} + \gamma_{m} h $$

where \( \gamma_{m} \) is the specific gravity of the manometer fluid. This simplifies to

$$ \mathrm{[4]} \; \; P_{g} = h \left( \gamma_{m} - \gamma_{o} \right) $$

Where \( P_{g} \) is gauge pressure. When measuring gas pressure, the fluid specific weight \( \gamma_{o} \) is negligible compared to the manometer fluid's specific weight \( \gamma_{m} \), so equation \( \mathrm{[4]} \) simplifies to

$$ \mathrm{[5]} \; \; P_{g} = \gamma_{m} h $$

In the case of an inclined manometer, fluid height \( h \) is related to the length of the manometer fluid \( L \) by:

$$ \mathrm{[6]} \; \; h = L \; \mathrm{sin} \theta $$

where \( \theta \) is the angle of the manometer tube. The advantage of using an inclined tube manometer is that slight changes in the fluid-side pressure \( P_{o} \) create significant changes to the length of the manometer fluid \( L \), so more precise measurements can be taken compared to a vertical U-tube manometer. If both ends of a manometer are closed (i.e. not open to atmosphere), a modified version of equation \( \mathrm{[4]} \) can be used:

$$ \mathrm{[7]} \; \; P_{o} + \gamma_{o} h = P_{c}(h) + \gamma_{m} h $$

where \( P_{c}(h) \) is the pressure in the closed end of the manometer as a function of the manometer fluid height \( h \). The ideal gas law can be used to define \( P_{c}(h) \). To simplify calculations, the closed end is often kept at vacuum, so \( P_{c}(h) = 0 \) and

$$ \mathrm{[8]} \; \; P_{o} = h \left( \gamma_{m} - \gamma_{o} \right) $$
